subject: Re: [junit] Re: Best approach for Unit testing asynch  responses?
msgSnippet: Not yet, but I am hosting a workshop on Programmer Testing at XP/Agile Universe next week. I suspect that an article will arise from that work. One of the
messageBody:
Not yet, but I am hosting a workshop on Programmer Testing at XP/Agile Universe next week. I suspect that an article will arise from that work. One of the topics will be the role of Programmer Tests.

I am also in the process of writing a book that will have some of my opinions on the subject sprinkled around, I'm sure.

Take care.

>So said y_shenhar on 2003-08-06 --------------------
>Have you written / know of any article about the difference between
>Programmer (unit) testing and Customer
>(integration/functional/acceptance) testing?
>
>
>
>--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@d...> wrote:
>> I prefer to make the distinction between Programmer Tests and
>Customer
>> Tests. If that interests you, then perhaps I'll write an article. I
>> haven't written one for a while. :)
>>
>> So said McCrann, Mike on 2002-11-14
>>
>> >I too am very interested in where people draw the line between unit
>> >testing and integration testing.
>> >Humphrey Sheil in his JavaWorld article "J2EE project dangers!"
>> >
>> >http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-03-2001/jw-0330-ten_p.html
>> >
>> >says that he would like to talk about: 'Unit testing versus
>> integration
>> >testing (when is testing done?)'
>> >
>> >Has anyone got any thoughts or references on the differences
>between
>> unit
>> >testing and integration testing. Some questions spring to mind:
>> >
>> >When should each be done?
>> >What you are trying to achieve with each?
>> >What asumptions you can make with each?
>> >
>> >Thanks
>> >
>> >-----Original Message-----
>> >From: nsparis [mailto:nathan_paris@a...]
>> >Sent: 13 November 2002 15:56
>> >To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>> >Subject: [junit] Re: Best approach for Unit testing asynch
>responses?
>> >
>> >
>> >You are referring to what I am doing as an "integration" test. Do
>> >you think this is no longer a unit test when I start making sure
>that
>> >the messenger is respondeing correctly when something is added?
>> >
>> >Should the unit test only make sure that the addMessage() method
>is
>> >working (I.e. it received the message), and the integration test
>> >should then make sure that when a certain message is added it
>> >recieves the correct response message via the listener?
>> >
>> >Thanks
>> >
>> >--- In junit@y..., "Michael Rettig" <mrettig@h...> wrote:
>> >> ----- Original Message -----
>> >> From: Mike Clark <mike@c...>
>> >> > >I have already implemented this with JUnit by making the
>> >> > >TestMessenger TestCase a MessengerLister. After I add a
>message
>> >I
>> >> > >sleep until a response is supplied. I then wake up (or time
>out
>> >for
>> >> > >failure) and test if this is the correct response to assert
>if
>> >the
>> >> > >test failed or passed.
>> >> > >
>> >> >
>> >> > Sounds like a reasonable integration test. That's generally
>the
>> >> > approach I take when faced with testing asynchronous messaging
>> >end-to-end.
>> >> >
>> >> > Mike
>> >>
>> >> Also, you can look at mocking your messenger layer. Whenever,
>I've
>> >done asynch testing, I found a way to make the testing
>synchronouse
>> >using a mock layer. This was ideal for simulating odd messaging
>> >behavior that could not be easily replicated asynchronously.
>> >>
>> >> Mike Rettig
